title: Graphical Analysis w Int by Parts and Improper Int

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the derivative of the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, is shown above for <math alttext="negative 1 less than x, less than 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> has exactly one horizontal tangent line, at <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis from <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of 0 equals negative 15" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g of 7 equals 13" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 7, of, g of x, d x, equals 22.4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>22.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) How many points of inflection does the graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> have on the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than x, is less than 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, the derivative of the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, is shown above for <math alttext="negative 1 less than x, less than 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> has exactly one horizontal tangent line, at <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="g prime" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> and the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis from <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="x equals 7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is known that <math alttext="g of 0 equals negative 15" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g of 7 equals 13" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 7, of, g of x, d x, equals 22.4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>22.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) How many points of inflection does the graph of <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> have on the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than x, is less than 8" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(b) Find the average value of <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, is less than or equal to 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(c) Must there exist a value of <math alttext="c" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than c, less than 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>c</mi><mo><</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, such that <math alttext="g of c equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(d) Evaluate <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 7, of, open parenthesis, 2 times g of x, plus 3, close parenthesis, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(e) Evaluate <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 0, of, the fraction with numerator g of x, plus 4 x, minus 4, and denominator sine x, plus 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(f) Let <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="h of x equals, e to the x power, times the integral from 7 to x, of, g of t, d t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="h prime of 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(g) The region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the base of a solid. For this solid, at each <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a rectangle with height <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and base in the region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The volume of the solid is given by <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 7, of, A of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an expression for <math alttext="A of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(h) What is the volume of the solid described in part (g)? Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(i) Find the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 7, of, the fraction with numerator g double prime of x, and denominator the square root of g prime of x, end root, end fraction, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo stretchy="true">∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><msqrt><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> or show that it does not exist. (Note: <math alttext="the indefinite integral of, the fraction 1 over the square root of x, end fraction, d x, equals 2 times the square root of x, end root, plus C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="true">∫</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msqrt><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msqrt><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>)

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
